HSC BiologyFoundational

Technologies in Cytology: How We See Cells

From Hooke's first glimpse of cork cells in 1665 to modern electron microscopes revealing molecular detail, discover how microscopy technology revolutionised our understanding of life at the cellular level.

üî¨

üéØ LEARNING INTENTIONS

  • Students can explain how light microscopes work and their limitations
  • Students can distinguish between SEM and TEM electron microscopes
  • Students can compare resolution and magnification across microscope types
  • Students can evaluate which microscope is appropriate for different specimens
  • Students can interpret electron micrographs and identify cellular structures

üîó KEY CONNECTIONS

  • Prior: Cell structure, organelles, prokaryotic vs eukaryotic cells
  • Future: Calculating magnification and actual size (next lesson)
  • Real World: Medical diagnostics, forensics, materials science, quality control
  • HSC Skills: Analysing microscope images, selecting appropriate technologies

‚úÖ SUCCESS CRITERIA

  • I can describe how light microscopes form magnified images
  • I can explain the difference between magnification and resolution
  • I can compare light, SEM, and TEM microscopes using a table
  • I can identify which microscope produced a given image
  • I can justify microscope choice for specific biological questions
üëÅÔ∏è

Why We Need Microscopes: The Scale Problem

Most cells are invisible to the naked eye. The resolution of the human eye is approximately 0.1 mm (100 Œºm)‚Äîwe cannot distinguish two points closer together than this distance. Since most animal cells are 10‚Äì30 Œºm and bacteria are 1‚Äì5 Œºm, microscopes are essential for studying cellular biology.

StructureTypical SizeVisible to Naked Eye?Technology Needed
Human height~1.7 m (1,700,000 Œºm)‚úÖ YesNone
Human egg cell~120 Œºm‚úÖ Just visible (barely)None, but microscope helps
Typical plant cell10‚Äì100 Œºm‚ùå NoLight microscope
Typical animal cell10‚Äì30 Œºm‚ùå NoLight microscope
Mitochondrion1‚Äì10 Œºm‚ùå NoLight microscope (limited detail)
Bacterium0.5‚Äì5 Œºm‚ùå NoLight microscope
Ribosome~0.025 Œºm (25 nm)‚ùå NoElectron microscope only
DNA double helix width~0.002 Œºm (2 nm)‚ùå NoElectron microscope only
üí° Key Concept: Magnification is how much larger an image appears compared to the actual specimen. Resolution is the ability to distinguish two points as separate. High magnification is useless without high resolution‚Äîyou'll just see a blurry, enlarged image.
üîç

Light Microscopes (Optical Microscopes)

The light microscope (also called an optical or compound microscope) uses visible light and glass lenses to magnify specimens. First developed in the late 1500s and perfected by the 1800s, light microscopes remain essential tools in biology laboratories worldwide.

How Light Microscopes Work

üí°

1. ILLUMINATION

Light source (lamp or mirror) provides visible light that passes through the specimen

Note: Specimens must be thin enough for light to pass through (transparent or translucent)
‚Üì
üéØ

2. OBJECTIVE LENS

First magnification step‚Äîlens close to specimen creates enlarged image

Common powers: 4√ó, 10√ó, 40√ó, 100√ó (oil immersion)
‚Üì
üëÅÔ∏è

3. EYEPIECE LENS

Second magnification step‚Äîfurther enlarges the image from the objective

Standard power: 10√ó (occasionally 15√ó or 20√ó)
‚Üì
üñºÔ∏è

4. FINAL IMAGE

Total magnification = objective √ó eyepiece

Example: 40√ó objective √ó 10√ó eyepiece = 400√ó total magnification

Light Microscope Specifications

PropertyValueExplanation
Maximum useful magnification~1500√óHigher magnification produces blurry images due to resolution limits
Maximum resolution~0.2 Œºm (200 nm)Limited by wavelength of visible light (~400‚Äì700 nm)
Image typeColour (natural or stained)Uses visible light, so specimens appear in colour
Specimen preparationCan view living or dead cellsWet mounts allow observation of living, moving organisms
Specimen thicknessMust be thin and transparentLight must pass through; thick specimens appear dark/opaque
CostLow (AU$500‚Äì$10,000)Affordable for schools and basic research
üí° Staining: Most cells are transparent and colourless, making them difficult to see under a light microscope. Biological stains are coloured dyes that bind to specific structures, increasing contrast. Examples include iodine (stains starch in plant cells), methylene blue (stains nuclei), and eosin (stains cytoplasm pink).

Advantages and Limitations

Advantages ‚úÖLimitations ‚ùå
Can observe living specimens in real timeLimited resolution (~200 nm)‚Äîcannot see organelles clearly
Relatively inexpensive and portableLimited magnification (~1500√ó maximum useful)
Easy sample preparation (wet mounts)Specimens must be thin and transparent
Produces colour images (natural or stained)Cannot resolve structures smaller than ~200 nm (e.g. ribosomes, viruses)
Simple to operate, minimal training requiredImage quality decreases at high magnifications
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Students often confuse magnification with resolution. You can magnify an image to 10,000√ó with a light microscope, but it will be blurry because the resolution limit is ~200 nm. Resolution is determined by the wavelength of light/electrons used, not the power of the lenses.
‚ö°

Electron Microscopes: Breaking the Light Barrier

Invented in the 1930s, electron microscopes use beams of electrons instead of visible light. Because electrons have much shorter wavelengths than light (~0.005 nm compared to ~500 nm), electron microscopes achieve resolution up to 0.1 nm‚Äî2000 times better than light microscopes.

üí° The Wavelength-Resolution Relationship: Resolution is limited by the wavelength of the illumination source. Shorter wavelengths allow finer detail to be resolved. Electrons behave as waves with wavelengths ~100,000 times shorter than visible light, enabling vastly superior resolution.

There are two main types of electron microscopes, each with distinct advantages and applications: Transmission Electron Microscopes (TEM) and Scanning Electron Microscopes (SEM).

Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM)

The TEM transmits a beam of electrons through an ultra-thin specimen (50‚Äì100 nm thick). Electrons that pass through are detected to form a two-dimensional image showing internal structures.

PropertyValueExplanation
Maximum magnification~50,000,000√ó (50 million)Can visualise individual molecules and atomic structures
Resolution~0.1 nmCan resolve individual proteins and even large atoms
Image type2D cross-section, black and whiteShows internal structure; electrons absorbed = dark, transmitted = light
Specimen preparationDead cells only; ultra-thin slices (50‚Äì100 nm)Specimens fixed, dehydrated, embedded in resin, sliced with ultramicrotome
EnvironmentHigh vacuum requiredAir molecules would scatter electrons; living tissue cannot survive
Best forInternal ultrastructure of organellesViewing nucleus, mitochondria, ER, ribosomes, cell membranes
CostVery high (AU$500,000‚Äì$5 million)Requires specialised facility and trained operators

üìù Reading a TEM Image

Appearance: TEM images are black and white (grayscale). Dark regions indicate areas where electrons were absorbed (dense structures like membranes, DNA, ribosomes). Light regions indicate areas where electrons passed through (less dense cytoplasm, empty spaces).

What you can see: Double membrane of nucleus, cristae inside mitochondria, rough ER with ribosomes attached, stacks of Golgi cisternae, individual ribosomes (~25 nm), cell membranes (~7 nm thick).

What you cannot see: Colour, 3D surface detail, living cells, structures larger than the ultra-thin slice.

Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM)

The SEM scans a focused beam of electrons across the surface of a specimen. Electrons that bounce back (reflected or secondary electrons) are detected to create a three-dimensional image of the surface topology.

PropertyValueExplanation
Maximum magnification~2,000,000√ó (2 million)Lower than TEM but still vastly exceeds light microscopes
Resolution~0.5‚Äì10 nmLower than TEM but sufficient for surface detail
Image type3D surface view, black and white (or false colour)Shows surface texture and shape; depth of field creates 3D appearance
Specimen preparationDead cells; coated with thin metal layer (gold or platinum)Metal coating conducts electrons and prevents charging; specimens dried
EnvironmentHigh vacuum requiredSame reason as TEM; no living specimens possible
Best forSurface structure and 3D shapeViewing cell surface features, bacteria shape, pollen grains, insects
CostHigh (AU$300,000‚Äì$2 million)Less expensive than TEM but still requires specialised facility

üìù Reading an SEM Image

Appearance: SEM images appear three-dimensional with depth and shadow, like a landscape photograph. They are grayscale but often artificially coloured for visual appeal or to highlight features (these colours are not real).

What you can see: External shape of cells, surface texture, 3D arrangement of bacteria, pollen grain surface patterns, red blood cell biconcave shape, microvilli on intestinal cells.

What you cannot see: Internal structures (no cross-section), true colour, living cells, fine internal detail like TEM shows.

üö´ Exam Trap: SEM and TEM images are always black and white (grayscale). Any colours you see in electron micrographs are 'false colour' added artificially by computers to enhance contrast or highlight structures. Do not describe electron microscope images as 'coloured' in exams‚Äîthis loses marks.
‚öñÔ∏è

Comparing the Three Microscope Types

Choosing the appropriate microscope depends on your research question, specimen type, and the level of detail required. This comparison table summarises the key differences.

FeatureLight MicroscopeTEMSEM
Illumination sourceVisible lightElectron beam (transmitted)Electron beam (reflected/scattered)
Maximum magnification~1500√ó~50,000,000√ó~2,000,000√ó
Resolution~200 nm~0.1 nm~0.5‚Äì10 nm
Image appearanceColour (natural/stained)2D cross-section, grayscale3D surface, grayscale (or false colour)
Living specimens?‚úÖ Yes‚ùå No (vacuum kills cells)‚ùå No (vacuum kills cells)
Specimen preparationSimple (wet mount, staining)Complex (fixation, ultra-thin slicing)Complex (fixation, metal coating)
Best for viewingWhole cells, tissues, living organismsInternal ultrastructure of organellesSurface details and 3D shape
Can see ribosomes?‚ùå No (too small, ~25 nm)‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Sometimes (on surfaces)
Can see viruses?‚ùå No (20‚Äì300 nm, below resolution)‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes
Depth of fieldShallow (single focal plane)Very shallow (2D slice)Excellent (3D appearance)
CostLow ($500‚Äì$10,000)Very high ($500,000‚Äì$5 million)High ($300,000‚Äì$2 million)
AccessibilityAvailable in schoolsUniversities and research institutes onlyUniversities and research institutes only
üí° Choosing the Right Tool: If you need to observe living cells, movement, or cell behaviour, use a light microscope. If you need to see internal organelle structure at high resolution, use TEM. If you need 3D surface detail or want to view the shape/arrangement of cells, use SEM.
üî¨

Real-World Applications of Microscopy

Microscopy technologies are essential across medicine, research, forensics, and industry. Understanding which microscope to use for each application is a key HSC skill.

ApplicationMicroscope TypeReason
Diagnosing malaria from blood smearLight microscopeParasites visible in red blood cells; staining with Giemsa dye shows parasites clearly; rapid, inexpensive diagnosis
Counting sperm motility (fertility testing)Light microscopeMust observe living, moving sperm; light microscope allows real-time observation of motility
Identifying pollen grains (forensics/allergies)SEM3D surface patterns are species-specific and crucial for identification; SEM reveals detailed surface ornamentation
Studying mitochondrial cristae structureTEMCristae are internal membrane folds requiring ultra-high resolution cross-sections to visualise; only TEM has sufficient resolution
Detecting viruses in infected tissueTEMViruses (20‚Äì300 nm) are below the resolution limit of light microscopes; TEM can resolve viral particles and internal structure
Examining cancer cell surface changesSEMCancer cells often have altered surface features (microvilli loss, membrane blebbing); 3D surface imaging shows these changes
Observing onion cell mitosis stagesLight microscopeWhole cells and chromosome movement visible with staining; living or freshly prepared tissue required
Quality control: bacteria contamination in foodLight microscopeQuick, inexpensive detection; bacteria size (~1‚Äì5 Œºm) within light microscope resolution; can use gram staining
Research: protein localisation within cellsTEM (with immunogold labelling)Requires ultra-high resolution to see subcellular protein distribution; gold nanoparticles attached to antibodies appear as dark dots in TEM
Viewing red blood cell shape (biconcave discs)SEM3D shape is the key feature; SEM clearly shows biconcave disc topology and any abnormalities (e.g. sickle cell disease)
‚ö†Ô∏è HSC Exam Strategy: When asked to select an appropriate microscope, justify your answer by referencing: (1) whether the specimen is living or dead, (2) the size of structures you need to see, (3) whether you need surface or internal detail, and (4) whether 2D or 3D imaging is required. Always link your choice to resolution requirements.

üìã COPY INTO YOUR BOOKS

Light Microscope

  • Uses visible light and glass lenses
  • Max magnification: ~1500√ó
  • Resolution: ~200 nm (limited by light wavelength)
  • Can view living specimens
  • Produces colour images (natural or stained)
  • Inexpensive and widely accessible

Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM)

  • Transmits electron beam through ultra-thin specimen
  • Max magnification: ~50,000,000√ó
  • Resolution: ~0.1 nm
  • Dead cells only (vacuum required)
  • 2D cross-section, grayscale images
  • Best for internal ultrastructure

Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM)

  • Scans electron beam across specimen surface
  • Max magnification: ~2,000,000√ó
  • Resolution: ~0.5‚Äì10 nm
  • Dead cells only (vacuum required)
  • 3D surface view, grayscale (or false colour)
  • Best for surface topology and shape

Key Concepts

  • Magnification = how much larger image appears
  • Resolution = ability to distinguish two points
  • Shorter wavelength = better resolution
  • Electron wavelength ~100,000√ó shorter than light
  • All electron microscope images are grayscale
  • Choose microscope based on specimen and question

mcq.question: What is the primary advantage of electron microscopes over light microscopes?
options: They are less expensive and more portable
They can view living specimens in real time
They have much higher resolution due to shorter electron wavelengths
They produce natural colour images
mcq.explanation: Electron microscopes achieve resolution up to 0.1 nm compared to light microscopes' ~200 nm limit. This is because electrons have wavelengths ~100,000 times shorter than visible light.

mcq.question: Which microscope would be most appropriate for observing the 3D surface structure of a pollen grain?
options: Light microscope
Transmission electron microscope (TEM)
Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
Any of the above would be equally suitable
mcq.explanation: SEM specialises in 3D surface imaging with excellent depth of field, perfect for viewing pollen surface patterns.

mcq.question: A biology student observes a cell image showing mitochondrial cristae and individual ribosomes as dark dots. The image is grayscale and appears as a 2D cross-section. Which microscope produced this image?
options: Light microscope with staining
Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
Transmission electron microscope (TEM)
Light microscope with phase contrast
mcq.explanation: The combination of grayscale image, internal ultrastructure (cristae), visible ribosomes (~25 nm, below light microscope resolution), and 2D cross-section appearance all indicate TEM.

mcq.question: Why can electron microscopes NOT be used to observe living cells?
options: Electrons are too large to pass through cell membranes
The high vacuum required would kill the cells
Living cells are too large to fit in the microscope chamber
Living cells do not absorb electrons
mcq.explanation: Electron microscopes require a vacuum because air molecules would scatter electrons. This vacuum instantly kills living cells by removing all water and air.

mcq.question: What limits the resolution of a light microscope to approximately 200 nm?
options: The maximum magnification of the objective lens
The wavelength of visible light
The thickness of glass lenses
The brightness of the light source
mcq.explanation: Resolution is fundamentally limited by the wavelength of the illumination source (~400-700 nm for visible light). Structures smaller than approximately half the wavelength cannot be resolved.

saq.question: Explain the difference between magnification and resolution. Why is resolution more important than magnification when viewing small cellular structures?
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Correct definition of magnification (degree of enlargement)
1 mark: Correct definition of resolution (ability to distinguish separate points)
1 mark: Explanation that resolution determines detail/clarity, high magnification without resolution just shows blur
saq.modelAnswer: Magnification is the degree to which an object's image is enlarged compared to its actual size. Resolution is the ability to distinguish two points as separate‚Äîthe minimum distance at which two points can be seen as distinct. Resolution is more important because it determines the level of detail visible. You can magnify an image to any size, but if resolution is insufficient, the image will simply be a larger blur without revealing fine structures.

saq.question: A researcher needs to study the internal structure of mitochondria, specifically the arrangement and spacing of cristae (inner membrane folds). Recommend the most appropriate microscope and justify your choice with reference to resolution and image type.
markingCriteria: 2 marks: Explanation of resolution requirements (cristae ~7 nm thick, TEM ~0.1 nm resolution, light microscope ~200 nm insufficient)
1 mark: Explanation of TEM's 2D cross-section advantage for internal structures
saq.modelAnswer: Transmission electron microscope (TEM). Mitochondrial cristae are internal membrane folds approximately 7 nm thick with spacing of 10-30 nm between folds. These structures are far below the ~200 nm resolution limit of light microscopes. TEM provides resolution of ~0.1 nm, which easily resolves cristae structure and allows precise measurement of membrane spacing. Additionally, TEM produces 2D cross-sectional images that clearly show the internal arrangement of cristae within mitochondria.

saq.question: Compare TEM and SEM electron microscopes. Include in your answer: (a) How each type produces an image (2 marks), (b) The type of information each provides (2 marks), (c) One advantage of each type over the other (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 2 marks: TEM transmits electrons through ultra-thin specimen; SEM scans electrons across surface
2 marks: TEM shows internal ultrastructure; SEM shows 3D surface topology
2 marks: TEM advantage (higher resolution ~0.1 nm); SEM advantage (3D surface view, depth of field)
saq.modelAnswer: (a) TEM transmits a beam of electrons through an ultra-thin specimen (50-100 nm). Electrons that pass through are detected to form a 2D image. SEM scans a focused electron beam across the specimen's surface. Electrons that bounce back are detected to create a 3D surface image. (b) TEM provides information about internal cellular ultrastructure‚Äîcross-sections of organelles and membrane layers. SEM provides information about external surface topology, 3D shape, and spatial arrangement. (c) TEM advantage: Much higher resolution (~0.1 nm vs ~0.5-10 nm), allowing visualisation of molecular structures. SEM advantage: Provides 3D surface images with excellent depth of field, whereas TEM only produces 2D cross-sections.

activities.content:
Light Microscope: Can view living specimens, Produces colour images, Resolution ~200 nm

TEM: Produces 2D cross-section images, Maximum ~50,000,000√ó magnification, Resolution ~0.1 nm, Best for internal ultrastructure

SEM: Shows 3D surface topology, Specimens coated with gold/platinum, Best for surface detail

activities.title: Activity 2: Match Image to Microscope
activities.content:
TEM images: Grayscale, 2D cross-sections showing internal structures (cristae, ribosomes, nuclear envelope)

Light Microscope images: Colour (natural or stained), transparent cells, living specimens visible

SEM images: 3D surface view with depth and shadow, grayscale, shows external topology

activities.title: Activity 3: Resolution Order
activities.content:
Correct order (lowest to highest resolution):

  1. Human eye (~100 Œºm = 100,000 nm)
  2. Light microscope (~200 nm)
  3. SEM (~1 nm or better)
  4. TEM (~0.1 nm)

Resolution improves as wavelength decreases. Visible light (~500 nm) limits light microscopes. Electrons have wavelengths ~0.005 nm, enabling vastly superior resolution.

activities.title: Activity 4: Match Application to Microscope
activities.content:
Malaria diagnosis: Light microscope - parasites visible in stained blood; rapid, inexpensive

Sperm motility: Light microscope - must observe living, moving sperm in real time

Pollen identification: SEM - 3D surface patterns are species-specific; SEM reveals detailed ornamentation

Cristae structure: TEM - internal membrane structures require ultra-high resolution cross-sections

Virus detection: TEM - viruses (20-300 nm) are below light microscope resolution

assessment.question: What is the primary advantage of electron microscopes over light microscopes?
assessment.answer: C - They have much higher resolution due to shorter electron wavelengths
assessment.explanation: Electrons have wavelengths ~100,000 times shorter than visible light, enabling resolution up to 0.1 nm compared to light microscopes' ~200 nm limit.

assessment.question: Which microscope would be most appropriate for observing the 3D surface structure of a pollen grain?
assessment.explanation: SEM specialises in 3D surface imaging with excellent depth of field, perfect for viewing pollen surface patterns.

assessment.question: A biology student observes a cell image showing mitochondrial cristae and individual ribosomes as dark dots. The image is grayscale and appears as a 2D cross-section. Which microscope produced this image?
assessment.explanation: The combination of grayscale image, internal ultrastructure (cristae), visible ribosomes (~25 nm, below light microscope resolution), and 2D cross-section appearance all indicate TEM.

assessment.question: Why can electron microscopes NOT be used to observe living cells?
assessment.answer: B - The high vacuum required would kill the cells
assessment.explanation: Electron microscopes require a vacuum because air molecules would scatter electrons. This vacuum instantly kills living cells by removing all water and air.

assessment.question: What limits the resolution of a light microscope to approximately 200 nm?
assessment.answer: B - The wavelength of visible light
assessment.explanation: Resolution is fundamentally limited by the wavelength of the illumination source (~400-700 nm for visible light). Structures smaller than approximately half the wavelength cannot be resolved.

assessment.question: Explain the difference between magnification and resolution. Why is resolution more important than magnification when viewing small cellular structures?
assessment.answer: Magnification is the degree to which an object's image is enlarged compared to its actual size. Resolution is the ability to distinguish two points as separate‚Äîthe minimum distance at which two points can be seen as distinct rather than blurred together. Resolution is more important than magnification because it determines the level of detail and clarity that can be observed. You can magnify an image to any size, but if the resolution is insufficient, the image will simply be a larger blur without revealing fine structures. For example, a light microscope can magnify to 10,000√ó, but if the resolution limit is 200 nm, structures smaller than this (like ribosomes at 25 nm) will never be visible no matter how much you magnify.

assessment.question: A researcher needs to study the internal structure of mitochondria, specifically the arrangement and spacing of cristae. Recommend the most appropriate microscope and justify your choice.
assessment.answer: Recommended microscope: Transmission electron microscope (TEM). Justification: Mitochondrial cristae are internal membrane folds approximately 7 nm thick with spacing of 10-30 nm between folds. These structures are far below the ~200 nm resolution limit of light microscopes, making them invisible or appearing only as vague shadows. TEM provides resolution of ~0.1 nm, which easily resolves cristae structure and allows precise measurement of membrane spacing. Additionally, TEM produces 2D cross-sectional images that clearly show the internal arrangement of cristae within mitochondria. The ultra-thin slicing technique allows visualization of cristae in different planes. SEM would not be suitable as it only shows external surfaces, and light microscopy lacks the resolution for this level of detail.

assessment.question: Compare TEM and SEM electron microscopes.
assessment.answer: (a) Image formation: TEM transmits a beam of electrons through an ultra-thin specimen (50-100 nm). Electrons that pass through are detected by sensors below the specimen. Dense structures absorb more electrons and appear dark; less dense regions appear light, creating a 2D grayscale cross-sectional image. SEM scans a focused electron beam across the specimen's surface in a raster pattern. Electrons that bounce back (secondary or backscattered electrons) are detected. The intensity of reflected electrons at each point determines brightness, building up a 3D surface image with depth and shadow. (b) Information provided: TEM provides information about internal cellular ultrastructure and subcellular organisation. Shows cross-sections of organelles (mitochondrial cristae, rough ER with ribosomes, nuclear envelope). SEM provides information about external surface topology, 3D shape, and spatial arrangement. Shows surface texture, patterns, and overall morphology with excellent depth of field. (c) Advantages: TEM advantage over SEM‚Äîmuch higher resolution (~0.1 nm vs ~0.5-10 nm), allowing visualisation of molecular-level structures such as individual proteins and ribosomes. Higher magnification capability (~50 million√ó vs ~2 million√ó). SEM advantage over TEM‚Äîprovides 3D surface images with excellent depth of field, whereas TEM only produces 2D cross-sections. Sample preparation is simpler (metal coating vs ultra-thin slicing).
